title-group.article-title: On the Iteratively Regularized Gauss-Newton Method for Solving Nonlinear Ill-Posed Problems

abstract.p: The iteratively regularized Gauss-Newton method is applied to compute the stable solutions to nonlinear ill-posed problems F(x) = y when the data y is given approximately by y<sup>δ</sup> with |y<sup>δ</sup> - y| ≤ δ. In this method, the iterative sequence {x<sup>δ</sup><sub>k</sub>} is defined successively by x<sup>δ</sup><sub>k+1</sub> = x<sup>δ</sup><sub>k</sub> - (α<sub>k</sub> I + F'(x<sup>δ</sup><sub>k</sub>)<sup>*</sup> F'(x<sup>δ</sup><sub>k</sub>))<sup>-1</sup> (F'(x<sup>δ</sup><sub>k</sub>)<sup>*</sup> (F(x<sup>δ</sup><sub>k</sub>) - y<sup>δ</sup>) + α<sub>k</sub> (x<sup>δ</sup><sub>k</sub> - x<sub>0</sub>)), where x<tex-math>$^\delta_0:= x_0$</tex-math> is an initial guess of the exact solution x<sup>†</sup> and {α<sub>k</sub>} is a given decreasing sequence of positive numbers admitting suitable properties. When x<sup>δ</sup><sub>k</sub> is used to approximate x<sup>†</sup>, the stopping index should be designated properly. In this paper, an a posteriori stopping rule is suggested to choose the stopping index of iteration, and with the integer k<sub>δ</sub> determined by this rule it is proved that <tex-math>$\|x^\delta_{k_\delta} - x^\dagger\| \leq C \inf \{\|x_k - x^\dagger\| + \frac{\delta}{\sqrt{\alpha_k}\}: k = 0, 1,...}$</tex-math> with a constant C independent of δ, where x<sub>k</sub> denotes the iterative solution corresponding to the noise free case. As a consequence of this result, the convergence of x<sup>δ</sup><sub>k<sub>δ</sub></sub> is obtained, and moreover the rate of convergence is derived when x<sub>0</sub> - x<sup>†</sup> satisfies a suitable "source-wise representation". The results of this paper suggest that the iteratively regularized Gauss-Newton method, combined with our stopping rule, defines a regularization method of optimal order for each <latex>$0 < \nu \leq$</latex> 1. Numerical examples for parameter estimation of a differential equation are given to test the theoretical results.
